sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying coil
message_1: A physics student needs to find the magnetic field strength at the center of a circular loop of wire carrying a current of 5 A and a radius of 0.1 m.
message_2:
To find the magnetic field strength at the center of a circular loop of wire, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a current-carrying loop:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * R)

where B is the magnetic field strength, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current in the wire, and R is the radius of the loop.

Given the current I = 5 A and the radius R = 0.1 m, we can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A) / (2 * 0.1 m)

B = (20π × 10^(-7) Tm) / 0.2 m

B = 100π × 10^(-7) T

B ≈ 3.14 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field strength at the center of the circular loop of wire is approximately 3.14 × 10^(-5) T (tesla).
